column1: Sunnybank is a suburb in the City of Brisbane
column5: 697 people.Sunnybank is known for its high level of Asian population and the Asian shops and restaurants in the area.

column1: The Jagera Indigenous people were the first to inhabit the area well over 20
column2: 000 years ago. Early settlers noticed that the Sunnybank district had good rainfall and a beautiful loamy soil
column4: that produced beautiful displays of natural wild flowers. From the mid-19th century it developed into a farming area with prosperous fruit and poultry farms and gardens of every kind.

column1: The Town of Sunnybank in the 19th century was part of a much larger area known as the Parish of Yeerongpilly
column2: but a distinct town outside of the area known as Brisbane. In 1885
column3: the railway line was extended from Yeerongpilly
column4: and names had to be given to the railway stations along the line. Sunnybank got its name from a local farm
column8: 100 m2) of land were taken over for the railway. Brae is Scottish for the English word bank
column9: so the area was given boundaries and named Sunnybank.

column1: The present suburb much reduced in size from the previous suburb of Sunnybank. The separate town of Sunnybank was absorbed into the City of Brisbane in 1925. This older Sunnybank area is still known locally as Sunnybank. Rolling hills and the headwaters for both Stable Swamp Creek and Bulimba Creek have drawn people and wildlife to the Sunnybank area.
By the first part of the 20th century
column2: farmland increasingly gave way to suburbia. General Motors Holden established a car manufacturing plant on Bradman Street at Acacia Ridge
column3: creating a major source of employment for the entire city of Brisbane.

column4: swimming pools and a mini zoo became Brisbane's most popular tourist attraction. The Oasis was located at 141 Station Road

column1: With the 1982 Commonwealth Games being held at the Queen Elizabeth II sporting complex (QE II)
column2: now known as the Queensland Sport and Athletics Centre (QSAC)
column4: Brisbane and its suburbs like Sunnybank were shown to the world. With new land releases rare in the region
column5: developers have turned to building higher density residential and commercial projects.

column2: an increasing number of Asian immigrants began to settle in Sunnybank and neighbouring suburbs. The influx of Asian immigrants caused the look of the area to change
column3: especially in the primary business district of Sunnybank at the intersection of Mains Road and McCullough Street
column4: where Asian restaurants and businesses are numerous.

column1: Sunnybank is today a thriving multicultural suburb
column2: with strong Asian influences in design
column3: food and culture. Many of the suburb's shops and businesses are owned and run by people of Asian descent who call Australia home
column4: with many bilingual business signs written in Chinese and English.
50.3% female and 49.7% male. The median age of the Sunnybank population was 34 years
column5: 3 years below the Australian median. 44.1% of people living in Sunnybank were born in Australia

column2: Sunnybank railway station and Altandi railway station provides access to regular Queensland Rail City network services to Brisbane and Beenleigh.

column1: Sunnybank State School is a government primary (Prep-6) school for boys and girls at 50 Eddington Street (27.5756°S 153.0514°E﻿ / -27.5756; 153.0514﻿ (Sunnybank State School)). It includes a Special Education Program. In 2017
column2: the school had an enrolment of 340 students with 27 teachers (22 full-time equivalent) and 19 non-teaching staff (11 full-time equivalent).Despite its name
column3: Runcorn State School is a government primary (Prep-6) school for boys and girls at 646 Beenleigh Road in Sunnybank (27.5881°S 153.0621°E﻿ / -27.5881; 153.0621﻿ (Runcorn State School)). It includes a Special Education Program and a Special Education Unit. In 2017
column4: the school had an enrolment of 437 students with 33 teachers (27 full-time equivalent) and 19 non-teaching staff (12 full-time equivalent).

column1: Sunnybank State High School is a government secondary (7-12) school for boys and girls at Boorman Street (27.5762°S 153.0597°E﻿ / -27.5762; 153.0597﻿ (Sunnybank State High School)). It includes the Sunnybank Special Education Unit. In 2017
column2: the school had an enrolment of 664 students with 67 teachers (63 full-time equivalent) and 42 non-teaching staff (32 full-time equivalent).Sunnybank Special School is a special primary and secondary (Early Childhood-12) school for boys and girls at 79 Troughton Road (27.5721°S 153.0483°E﻿ / -27.5721; 153.0483﻿ (Sunnybank Special School)). It includes an Early Childhood Development Program. In 2017
column3: the school had an enrolment of 38 students with 14 teachers (11 full-time equivalent) and 17 non-teaching staff (10 full-time equivalent).Our Lady of Lourdes Primary School is a Catholic primary (Prep-6) school for boys and girls at Shearwin Street (27.5816°S 153.0619°E﻿ / -27.5816; 153.0619﻿ (Our Lady of Lourdes Primary School)). In 2017
column4: the school had an enrolment of 509 students with 37 teachers (31 full-time equivalent) and 15 non-teaching staff (10 full-time equivalent).St Thomas More College is a Catholic secondary (7-12) school for boys and girls at the corner of Troughton Road & Turton Street (27.5737°S 153.0489°E﻿ / -27.5737; 153.0489﻿ (St Thomas More College)). In 2017
column5: the school had an enrolment of 1012 students with 75 teachers (74 full-time equivalent) and 34 non-teaching staff (27 full-time equivalent).Carinity Education is a private secondary (7-12) school for girls at 153 Lister Street (27.5778°S 153.0547°E﻿ / -27.5778; 153.0547﻿ (Carinity Education - Southside)). The school provides a supportive individual learning environment for girls who have difficulties with mainstream schooling. In 2017
column6: the school had an enrolment of 114 students with 10 teachers (8 full-time equivalent) and 18 non-teaching staff (14 full-time equivalent).
